title: Victory in campaign to scrap child burial fees for grieving parents
text:

In a major victory for the Sunday Mirror’s campaign to scrap child burial fees, the Welsh government has announced the charges are to go. 
Along with the Labour Party , we have been calling for an end to the unfair system that sees thousands of families a year hit with fees when they lose a child. 
At Labour Party conference in Wales, leader Carwyn Jones said: “Today I am pleased to confirm that the welsh Labour Government will step in, and make sure that burial charges for children will no longer apply in Welsh communities.” 
He also paid tribute to the “tenacious and dignified campaign” being fought by Labour Swansea East MP Carolyn Harris on funeral costs. Read More Scrapping child burial fees to end heartbreak for grieving families agreed by another council Welsh leader Carwyn Jones announced the scrapping of the charges (Photo: Daily Post Wales) 
Mrs Harris was forced to take out a loan when she lost her own son Martin in a crash. 
And she is leading the campaign to end the council-imposed charges for 5,000 children who die each year. 
The proposal would cost just £10m a year, a fraction of overall government spending. 
Mrs Harris said: “I’m delighted and proud that Labour in Wales has taken this decision. 
“We need the rest of the country to follow their example. 
“These are cruel charges at a time when people are at their most desperate and vulnerable. 
“There is nothing like the heartbreak of losing a child and it is within the government’s gift to try and ease the grief of these families just a little.” MP Carolyn Harris praised for her "tenacious and dignified campaign" (Photo: South Wales Evening Post) 
Introducing the policy in Wales is expected to cost between £750,000 and £1m per year. 
Kate Lee, Chief Executive of CLIC Sargent, said: “It’s fantastic news that the Welsh Government has decided to ease the financial burden of families grieving the loss of a child, especially in the same week that Co-Op Funeralcare announced that it will extend its free children’s funeral service to include 16 and 17 year-olds. 
“All too frequently, the cost of a funeral imposes crippling and unmanageable financial pressure on bereaved parents, during what is already an incredibly traumatic time. 
“Grieving parents should not be made to suffer this added indignity and distress and we will continue to fight for a children’s funeral fund to support families across the UK.” Like us on Facebook
